div1.p: Kean attempts to protect the original Yellow Fever Roll of Honor. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Memorandum from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Robert U. Patterson, May 26, 1933
div1.p: Subject: Protection of the Yellow Fever Roll of Honor.

1. Senator Cary of Wyoming, probably at the instance of
Senator Sheppard, introduced on May 12, 1933 a bill (S. 1587) to add
the name of Roger Post Ames to the Yellow Fever Roll of Honor (approved
Feb. 28, 1929). Mr. Beam introduced May 19, 1933 a bill (H.R. 5700)
to include in the Yellow Fever Roll of Honor the name of Gustaf E.
Lambert.

2. Full reports in both these cases opposing such action
should be on file in your office. Mr. McSwain, Chairman of the Mili-
tery Committee, is familiar with the demerits of both of these claiments
if he has not forgotten them and is opposed to both.

3. Attention is invited to an indorsement by me dated 12
March, 1929 on a letter of Mr. Gus F. Lambert in which he stated that
he recognized that it was impossible for the Government to reward all
the men who did meritorious service in the yellow fever work in Cuba,
and he would be content with an official statement of his service in
connection therewith. He was given such a statement including a
certificate by Capt. Thomas M. England then on duty in the S.G.O. He
now is apparently making this certificate of good service the basis
of a claim to be added to the Yellow Fever Roll of Honor. I was
interested in his getting this certificate because he nursed me in
the Yellow Fever Hospital at Columbia Barracks when I had yellow fever
in June, 1900. While Private Lambert served at the Yellow Fever
Hospital at Columbia Barracks, he was in no way connected with the
work of the Yellow Fever Commission nor did he volunteer to submit to
the experiments carried on by that Commission.

J. R. KEAN
Brig. Gen. U. S. Army, Retired.
